text: The in Japan was a set of four emperors during the Nanboku-chō period from 1336 through 1392.Nussbaum, Louis Frédéric and Käthe Roth. (2005). "Hokuchō," Japan Encyclopedia, p. 344. ==List of monarchs== *Emperor Go-Daigo, 1318–1339Nussbaum, "Go-Daigo Tennō" at p. 251. *Emperor Go-Murakami, 1339–1368Nussbaum, "Go-Murakami Tennō" at p. 257. *Emperor Chōkei, 1368–1383Nussbaum, "Chōkei Tennō" at p. 120. *Emperor Go-Kameyama, 1383–1392Nussbaum, "Go-Kameyama Tennō" at p. 253. After 1392, Go-Komatsu was the 100th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession.Nussbaum, "Hokuchō" at p. 344. ==List of monarch-created eras== During the Nanboku-chō period, the Southern Court monarchs recognized 11 Japanese era names (年号, nengō, lit. year names), including # Gentoku, 1329–1331 # Genkō, 1331–1334 # Kemmu, 1334–1336 # Engen, 1336–1340 # Kōkoku, 1340–1346 # Shōhei, 1346–1370 # Kentoku, 1370–1372 # Bunchū, 1372–1375 # Tenju, 1375–1381 # Kōwa, 1381–1384 # Genchū, 1384–1392 == Related pages== * Northern Court * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese era name == References == ==Other websites== * Metropolitan Museum of Art, Kamakura and Nanbokucho Periods (1185–1392), Muromachi Period (1392–1573) Category:14th century in Japan Category:1336 establishments in Japan Category:1390s disestablishments in Japan Category:1392 disestablishments
title: Southern Court
